title: 61 Hours
author: Lee Child
summary: In this Jack Reacher thriller by Lee Child, Reacher finds himself stranded in a small South Dakota town during a brutal winter storm. When a local police force asks for his help in protecting an elderly woman set to testify against a dangerous drug cartel, Reacher becomes entangled in a tense countdown toward a deadly confrontation. As the hours tick away, he uncovers hidden agendas, buried secrets, and a conspiracy that reaches further than anyone suspects. The cold and isolation amplify the tension, leading to one of the series' most intense and surprising conclusions.

title: Star Wars: Thrawn – Alliances
author: Timothy Zahn
summary: In this Star Wars novel by Timothy Zahn, Grand Admiral Thrawn and Darth Vader are reluctantly paired on a mission to the edges of the Unknown Regions, where threats to the Empire lurk. The story unfolds in two parallel timelines: one in the present, with Thrawn and Vader navigating their uneasy alliance, and one in the past, when Thrawn and Anakin Skywalker first crossed paths during the Clone Wars. The novel delves into Thrawn’s tactical genius, Vader’s power and rage, and the uneasy intersection of loyalty, ambition, and manipulation within the Empire.

title: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory
author: Roald Dahl
summary: Roald Dahl’s whimsical classic follows young Charlie Bucket, a poor but kind-hearted boy who wins a golden ticket to tour Willy Wonka’s extraordinary chocolate factory. Along with four other children, Charlie experiences fantastical rooms filled with chocolate rivers, everlasting gobstoppers, and Oompa-Loompas. Each child’s character flaws—greed, gluttony, pride, and selfishness—lead to their downfall, while Charlie’s humility and good nature earn him Wonka’s ultimate prize: ownership of the factory. The novel blends humor, moral lessons, and surreal imagination.

title: Tom Sawyer and Huckleberry Finn
author: Mark Twain
summary: Mark Twain’s adventures of Tom Sawyer and Huckleberry Finn follow two mischievous boys growing up along the Mississippi River in the mid-19th century. Tom’s adventures—ranging from tricking friends into whitewashing a fence to witnessing a murder—are filled with humor, danger, and youthful spirit. Huckleberry Finn’s story explores deeper themes of freedom and morality as he escapes his abusive father and travels down the river with Jim, a runaway slave. Together, the books capture the charm, mischief, and moral complexities of boyhood in a changing America.

title: The Hobbit
author: J.R.R. Tolkien
summary: J.R.R. Tolkien’s beloved fantasy novel follows Bilbo Baggins, a content hobbit whose quiet life is disrupted when the wizard Gandalf and a group of dwarves enlist him as their burglar for a daring quest to reclaim the Lonely Mountain from the dragon Smaug. Along the journey, Bilbo faces trolls, goblins, giant spiders, and the riddle-loving creature Gollum—where he acquires the mysterious One Ring. Through bravery and wit, Bilbo grows from a reluctant traveler into a cunning hero, in a tale rich with adventure, camaraderie, and world-building.

title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix
author: J.K. Rowling
summary: In the fifth book of J.K. Rowling’s Harry Potter series, Harry returns to Hogwarts to find the wizarding world in denial about Lord Voldemort’s return. The Ministry of Magic interferes with school affairs by installing Dolores Umbridge as the new Defense Against the Dark Arts teacher, whose oppressive rules spark rebellion. Harry forms Dumbledore’s Army to train students in defensive magic while grappling with visions linked to Voldemort. The story builds toward a battle in the Department of Mysteries, where revelations about prophecy, loyalty, and loss reshape Harry’s fight against the dark forces.

title: Don Quixote
author: Miguel de Cervantes
summary: Miguel de Cervantes’ masterpiece tells the tale of Alonso Quixano, a Spanish nobleman who, after reading too many chivalric romances, decides to become the self-styled knight Don Quixote. Accompanied by his loyal yet pragmatic squire, Sancho Panza, Don Quixote embarks on misguided adventures, mistaking windmills for giants and inns for castles. Blending satire, comedy, and tragedy, the novel explores themes of idealism versus reality, the power of imagination, and the human desire for purpose, ultimately becoming one of the most influential works in Western literature.
